references:
For our experiment on exploring the relationship between induced emotions and movie popularity, we also collected the data using community-built The Movie Database (TMDB)<sup class="ltx_note_mark">1</sup>
1<sup class="ltx_note_mark">1</sup>
11https://www.themoviedb.org with 904,555 movie metadata except for adult content and Deezer<sup class="ltx_note_mark">2</sup>
2<sup class="ltx_note_mark">2</sup>
22https://www.deezer.com music database. TMDB has a voting score from the community, therefore we used this data to analyze the correlation between the popularity of the movie and its emotional range and to represent the emotion distribution in 100 popular movies. Table I shows a snippet of the database containing 100 popular movies’ details. The movie’s overview as text, poster images in ’.jpg’ format, and a list of genres are taken from TMDB via the database’s API. As TMDB does not provide the soundtrack data, a 30-second clip from the original soundtrack was taken from Deezer API in ’.mp3’ format, requested by the track’s name and its performer, and transferred to ’.wav’.

S3.T2.table:
Rule # Agreement Confidence Feedback value
1 Strongly Agree Unsure Moderate
2 Strongly Agree Neutral Strong
3 Strongly Agree Sure Strong
4 Agree Unsure Moderate
5 Agree Neutral Moderate
6 Agree Sure Strong
7 Neutral Unsure Moderate
8 Neutral Neutral Moderate
9 Neutral Sure Strong
10 Disagree Unsure Moderate
11 Disagree Neutral Moderate
12 Disagree Sure Weak
13 Strongly Disagree Unsure Moderate
14 Strongly Disagree Neutral Weak
15 Strongly Disagree Sure Weak
references: The inference system uses a set of fuzzy rules to determine the consensus measure from the combination of agreement and confidence levels, as shown in Table II.

references: The final consensus measure for the group was evaluated by using the measure of statistical dispersion - Interquartile Range (IQR) (5) and the measure of central tendency - Mean (6) inference across all participants to obtain a crisp value indicating the group’s overall consensus, in Table III.

references: We surveyed individuals to examine their emotional reactions to 12 movies shown in Table IV, with responses categorized as Happy, Anger, Surprise, Sad, and Fear. Respondents were allowed to provide more than one emotional reaction for each question and were asked to list only the movies they had seen and their relevant feelings while watching them (see Fig. 8).

Let us show the example of selecting a movie for a group of people using the proposed approach. Given four movie viewers and a pool of 12 movie options (shown in Table IV), we aim to ensure satisfaction and provide the best movie recommendation for the participants.

references: The specific emotion score for a particular movie was calculated as the proportion of selection of this emotion among all choices made for this movie. The results are shown in Table V. Using data from three separate channels, the predicted scores for Happiness, Anger, Surprise, Sadness, and Fear are combined using (1). The results are shown in Table VIII.

Now, we can compare the prediction power of our approach by finding the similarity index between predicted emotion scores and the scores given by survey participants. Using the aggregated results of predicted scores (see Table VIII) and real human scores (Table V), we calculated the Jaccard distance (2) between the real and the predicted values of emotions for each movie (see Table VII). Afterward, we estimated the average similarity coefficient to be 0.76.

references: The specific emotion score for a particular movie was calculated as the proportion of selection of this emotion among all choices made for this movie. The results are shown in Table V. Using data from three separate channels, the predicted scores for Happiness, Anger, Surprise, Sadness, and Fear are combined using (1). The results are shown in Table VIII.

Now, we can compare the prediction power of our approach by finding the similarity index between predicted emotion scores and the scores given by survey participants. Using the aggregated results of predicted scores (see Table VIII) and real human scores (Table V), we calculated the Jaccard distance (2) between the real and the predicted values of emotions for each movie (see Table VII). Afterward, we estimated the average similarity coefficient to be 0.76.

Each participant provided information about their best-loved movie, a reference point for their preferences (see Table VI). Using the methods described in Section III, we conducted an emotional analysis of three primary sources associated with each movie: the movie poster (picture), the main soundtrack (music), and the movie description (text). Emotional data containing - Happiness, Anger, Surprise, Sadness, and Fear from the input are shown in Table VIII, and emotional data of best-loved movies of each participant is provided in Table IX.

Emotional scores from the three sources were aggregated using (1) for each of the 12 offered movies and four favorite movies. After that, we calculated the Jaccard similarity coefficient between each movie’s emotional composition and each participant’s best-loved movie. This process gives a Jaccard value indicating the similarity between the emotional composition of the 12 movies and the participants’ preferred choices, shown in Tables VIII and IX. The Box plot of predicted emotion scores is shown in Fig. 11.

references: Each participant provided information about their best-loved movie, a reference point for their preferences (see Table VI). Using the methods described in Section III, we conducted an emotional analysis of three primary sources associated with each movie: the movie poster (picture), the main soundtrack (music), and the movie description (text). Emotional data containing - Happiness, Anger, Surprise, Sadness, and Fear from the input are shown in Table VIII, and emotional data of best-loved movies of each participant is provided in Table IX.

Emotional scores from the three sources were aggregated using (1) for each of the 12 offered movies and four favorite movies. After that, we calculated the Jaccard similarity coefficient between each movie’s emotional composition and each participant’s best-loved movie. This process gives a Jaccard value indicating the similarity between the emotional composition of the 12 movies and the participants’ preferred choices, shown in Tables VIII and IX. The Box plot of predicted emotion scores is shown in Fig. 11.

references:
After determining the most recommended movie for the group, the level of consensus with the proposed movie was calculated using fuzzy logic by using participants’ feedback. Each participant was asked to rate their agreement with the recommended movie and their confidence levels in these agreements on a scale of 0 to 10, shown in Table X.
The feedback value was calculated based on fuzzy logic rules that used both the agreement and confidence scores, providing a nuanced measure of each participant’s satisfaction with the movie recommendation.

Following the defuzzification process, the centroid method obtained a clear answer. As a result of performing aggregation based on fuzzy rules, we get a feedback value equal to 5. The visual representation of the Rules as an example is shown in Fig. 12.
The feedback measure of all Participants was calculated and was shown in Table X.

S4.T11.caption: TABLE XI: Consensus scores of participants
S4.T11.table:
Interquartile Range
(IQR)
Mean Consensus level
1.18 5.54 High
Interquartile Range
(IQR)
references:
To evaluate the consensus among the group members regarding the recommended movie, we calculated the Interquartile Range (IQR) using Equation 5 and the mean of the feedback scores. The calculated IQR for the group’s feedback scores was <math alttext="\approx" class="ltx_Math" display="inline" id="S4.SS2.p7.1.m1.1">

≈5.54. These values indicate that the participants’ satisfaction level dispersion is relatively low. At the same time, the mean value is relatively high, suggesting a generally positive consensus about the movie recommendation, shown in Table XI. The low IQR value and high mean value demonstrated agreement among the group members and approved that the selected movie largely met the collective expectations and preferences of the participants.
